sub_title: Assistant Professor in Conflict Studies at Radboud University
summary:
Niels Terpstra is Assistant Professor in Conflict Studies at the Centre for International Conflict Analysis and Management (CICAM), Radboud University. His research focuses on the dynamics of civil war, political violence, insurgency, and terrorism. He is particularly interested in governance and legitimation practices of non-state armed groups during and after civil war. Furthermore, he is interested in foreign policy, particularly the political and strategic dimensions of peace- and state-building missions. 

Niels has published in the journals Small Wars & Insurgency, Civil Wars, Peacebuilding, Studies in Conflict & Terrorism, and Modern Asian Studies. He co-edited a special issue with Nelson Kasfir and Georg Frerks on ‘Armed Groups and Multi-layered Governance’, published in the journal of Civil Wars in 2017. Niels has field research experience in Afghanistan, Sri Lanka, Colombia, Germany and the Netherlands. Niels has taught courses on Conflict Analysis, Conflict Management, Peacebuilding, Conflict and Governance, and co-coordinated the UU Summer School on Contemporary Conflict and International Conflict Management. Niels’ dissertation on ‘Rebel Governance and Legitimacy in Afghanistan and Sri Lanka’ investigates how the Taliban in Afghanistan have governed territories under their control and how the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) governed in Sri Lanka. Moreover, it investigates how rebel governance affects civilian compliance with a rebel group and what this tells us about legitimacy, authority, and state formation processes. 

Over the past years, Niels was also involved in advisory and evaluation projects for the Netherlands Ministry of Justice and Security, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, peace organization PAX. Amongst others, this included the evaluation of the Dutch Police-training Mission in Kunduz, Afghanistan, an assessment of the Dutch government’s strategic narratives during the war in Afghanistan, the development of a Human security survey, a study on terrorism and the state of emergency in Western Europe, and the crime-terror nexus in the Netherlands. In 2018 Niels was invited by the US Embassy in the Hague to participate as expert in an IVLP program on (counter)terrorism in the United States. Furthermore, Niels has appeared on BBC Radio, NPO Radio 1 and in several Dutch national newspapers. In 2013, Niels received the J.C. Baak MA thesis prize for research on the enhancement of peaceful societies, awarded by the Royal Holland Society of Sciences and Humanities.

awards.title: Winner J.C. Baak Prijs 2012 -2013 (J.C. Baak Thesis Award 2012-2013)
awards.description:
De J.C. Baak Prijs wordt ter beschikking gesteld door de Koninklijke Hollandsche Maatschappij der Wetenschappen uit de baten die geschonken zijn door de J.C. Baak Stichting ter gelegenheid van de liquidatie van deze stichting. De Prijs bestaat uit een som gelds van 2.000 euro. De Prijs komt ten goede aan een student die een (master)scriptie heeft geschreven in één of meer van de volgende wetenschapsgebieden:

filosofie
rechtsgeleerdheid
politicologie
internationale betrekkingen
sociologie

Het onderzoek waaraan deze prijs wordt toegekend dient met name relevant te zijn voor het vreedzaam naast elkaar leven van verschillende volkeren.

De prijs wordt iedere twee jaar toegekend door het bestuur van de Maatschappij, na verkregen advies van een door de Maatschappij voor dit doel te benoemen commissie.

projects.title: Exploring opportunities for a Human Security Survey Tool
projects.description:
In the coming years PAX envisions to carry out a Human Security Survey throughout different developing countries relevant to PAX's mission. 

During this project me and Toon Dirkx were commissioned to explore the methodological challenges and opportunities for the envisioned Human Security Survey. We laid first hand on developing a ‘toolbox’ to survey human security dynamics and perspectives in order to gain a deeper understanding of security dynamics at the grassroots level. The survey tool uses a mixed method of qualitative and quantitaive elements and seeks to sample data relevant to human security in a way that can be repeated to track incidents, perceptions and trends.

projects.title: Youth Labor Market Action Research Pilot: Better-Targeted Vocational Training Activities for Youth
projects.description:
Contracted by: the Afghan NGO Co-operation for Peace and Unity (CPAU).

After more than three decades of violent conflict, Afghanistan is in need of a flexible and well-trained work force in order to further rebuild the country. Enduring violent conflict has broken down most Afghanistan’s training infrastructure and put the country down into one of the least developed in the world. One of the important factors holding Afghanistan’s development on hold is the absence of a well-educated and well-trained labor force. Most of the population lacks the skills and trades that the country needs to be able to grown economically. A better-trained youth will ensure higher levels of productivity and will support greater social mobility.

In cooperation with my Afghan partners of CPAU I worked on a proposed project and designed the methodology for participatory research-projects for youths in Khandahar and Khost, Afghanistan.

projects.title: Mining and Conflict: An In-depth Study of the Potential Resource Curse in of Afghanistan
projects.description:
Contracted by: the Afghan NGO Co-operation for Peace and Unity (CPAU).

The ongoing security transition in Afghanistan will be completed in 2014. Security issues regarding the withdrawal have, so far, dominated discussions about the country’s future. Parallel to this transition, however, the economic transition will take place. With billions of dollars in international aid decreasing over the subsequent years, Afghanistan will have to find a way to sustain its own economic future better than it has been doing over the past decade. Moreover, only the fact that PRT’s are closing throughout the country will already generate tens of thousands unemployed people. As our previous research has pointed out, the inability to make a livelihood can be a main driver of local violent conflict between communities. Hence, a responsible economic transition will be one of the major opportunities to support the security transition as well.

In cooperation with my Afghan counterparts of CPAU I developed a research proposal for funding.

profile_positions.description:
In 2018-2019 Toon Dirkx and Niels Terpstra carried out an analysis of the main developments in the police and justice sectors in Kunduz province, Afghanistan, between 2010 and 2018. The basis of the report was an extensive literature review and synthesis. The report was commissioned by the IOB, the evaluation unit of Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands. The report served as expert background to the IOB's post-mission evaluation of the Integrated Police-training Mission in Kunduz province, Afghanistan.

In 2015-2016 Toon Dirkx and Niels Terpstra carried out a study on strategic narratives surrounding the engagement of the Netherlands with the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan. This included an analysis of political discourse and media discussions along a timeline of key events. The report was commissioned by the Universität der Bundeswehr in Munich. The narrative analysis informed a synthesis report of five countries and was part of a larger project under the name ‘Lessons Learned Afghanistan’, carried out by the Universität der Bundeswehr in Munich.

volunteer_experiences.description: In 1976 the Netherlands – Sri Lanka (Ceylon) Foundation was established with the objective to promote good relations between the Netherlands and Sri Lanka in general and to promote cultural affairs and development cooperation in particular. In 2018 the scope of the objectives was widened to promote the social, cultural, economic, technological and academic relations between the Netherlands and Sri Lanka.

The Centre on Armed Groups supports efforts to analyze and engage with armed groups to reduce violence and end armed conflict. We do this through conducting innovative research, creating spaces for dialogue, and providing advice. The Centre is a resource for governments, researchers, humanitarians, peacebuilders and aid actors grappling with the challenges of engaging with armed groups.
